title: Failure Modes & Fallbacks: What Agents Do When Things Go Wrong
intent: Understand the most common ways agents fail in production and how to design explicit fallback strategies instead of silent breakdowns.

core_idea.one_liner: Agents will fail; the question is whether they fail safely.
why_it_matters: Silent failures destroy trust faster than explicit refusals.
Fallbacks turn errors into controlled outcomes.

definition.failure_mode: A known way in which an agent can produce incorrect, incomplete, or unsafe behavior.
definition.fallback: A predefined safe response or alternative path when a failure mode is detected.

common_failure_modes.fallback: Ask for missing inputs or state that verification is not possible.
Retry with backoff or switch to read-only / degraded mode.

common_failure_modes.symptom: Agent hits cost or latency limits.

fallback_design_principles: Fallbacks must be explicit, not accidental.
Fallbacks must be safe by default.
Users must understand why a fallback happened.

micro_example.scenario: Agent cannot retrieve required system metrics.

good_behavior.message: I cannot verify the current system state because metrics are unavailable.

guards: Never answer critical questions without evidence.

teach_it_in_english.simple_explanation: A good agent knows when to stop instead of guessing.
teach_it_in_english.one_sentence_definition: Fallbacks make agent failure predictable and safe.
